headline: White House stands by Gen. Kelly's criticism of Rep. Wilson
subHeadline: Rep. Frederica Wilson accuses Gen. John Kelly of 'lies' and racism, jokes she's a 'rock star' following fallen soldier firestorm; the debate continues on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: REP. FREDERICA WILSON, D-FLORIDA
utterances.sentences: You mean to tell me that I have to come forward.

utterances.speaker: WILSON
utterances.sentences: That the White House is following me and my work? This is amazing. That's amazing. That is absolutely phenomenal. I have to tell my kids that I'm a rock star now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wow. Rock star. She also made some serious charges after General Kelly accused her of politicizing the deaths of soldiers.

utterances.speaker: WILSON
utterances.sentences: I heard his remarks and I heard him say that I bragged that I secured the money for the building of the FBI building in Miramar? And that's a lie.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Well, his point was, I think, that though you're right, he didn't get the facts right on that was that empty barrels make the most noise.

utterances.speaker: WILSON
utterances.sentences: That's a racist term too. If I'm thinking about that when we looked it up in the dictionary because I have never heard of an empty barrel. And I don't like to be dragged into something like that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. Empty barrel is racist, Gutfeld. That is news to me.   GREG GUTFELD, "THE FIVE" CO-HOST: Yeah. Well, everything is racist these days. Stories like these are turning people inside out and I hate that we do them. I don't want to do these stories. I said it yesterday. No one walks away from these stories feeling any better about themselves or about the people they like or dislike. You just feel bad. I mean, Joy Reid. I don't know anything about her, but I look at these tweets that she has. This one where she says -- this is amazing to me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: General Kelly grew up in segregated Boston in an Irish Catholic neighborhood where women were bullied and blacks scorned and rejected. So she just labeled Irish Catholics racist and misogynist and by connection to that group, General Kelly. And this is a person that the media often ask, why doesn't she have her own show? But this is acceptable now. You can just call anybody or smear anybody as racist and people just run in fear. And the only thing -- it's so sad. The only thing that can save us from these stories, these emotional spasms, sadly, is real news. We're living in a superficial, ongoing squabble. But when there is a hurricane or terror attack, we suddenly realize what's good, what's real in life, and that's the sadness. Other countries which they had these problems, they wish they had this time to sit here and talk about this -- these ridiculous emotional conflicts. It's pathetic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And Joy Reid was referencing saying something was set on MSNBC. Let's play it and have Kim react to it.

utterances.speaker: LAWRENCE O'DONNEL, MSNBC ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: When John Kelly was going to school in Oak Square in Brighton, in the Boston Irish neighborhood that he grew up in, the schools were segregated by customs and practice. John Kelly never sat beside a student like Frederica Wilson in his elementary school. It was a neighborhood in which calling someone who like Frederica Wilson an empty barrel was the kindest thing that would have been said about her. Do you know what wasn't sacred when he was a kid growing up, where he was growing up? Black women or black people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Irresponsible.  KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, "THE FIVE" CO-HOST: It's so racist and awful and horrific, these kind of comments. I take personal issue with it as an Irish-Puerto Rican, double Catholic, to sit there in judgement, and make these statements about someone who has to serve our country faithfully, has lost his son, and continue to serve this country in an admirable way. What are these people thinking? Do they realize how awful this make them look and sound and really shows what's in their core? I mean, that's what's so disturbing to me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And CNN fact-checked whether double or empty barrel was racist, Juan, and they looked at Plato and Shakespeare, Abraham Lincoln used the phrase, they consulted etymology experts as well as the American dialect society and they found no relationship to racism ever with that phrase. JUAN WILLIAMS, "THE FIVE" CO-HOST: I was a puzzled myself. So when I walked in I said this to Greg, I said how did race get in? I mean, I don't like it, you know, when people say something that is, to my mind, without foundation, especially with regard to race, because to me, it then cheapens the whole thing because I think we had racism in this country. But I just wanted to say -- so I think this has become like a scrum now. Everybody is just kind of jumping in. But I tend to, given my -- the way I look at the world, want to get to the facts.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And so, when he says, when General Kelly says, oh, she took credit for the funding of the FBI headquarters in Miramar, Florida. I thought, well, so maybe that's what he means by empty barrel. That she takes credit for things that she didn't do. Then a video comes out and it shows that she did not take credit for it and he was wrong. This is to me, reminding of what happened yesterday when I thought as President Trump had tweeted that she fabricated everything with regards to this conversation he said was a secret conversation between him and the widow. Well, then it comes out, no, General Kelly says no, that President Trump did say, you know, the soldier knew what he was buying into when he went -- because he enlisted of his own volition. Well, turns out, Frederica Wilson was right again. So I think to myself, wow, why are people beating up Frederica Wilson when she in fact has been right twice.  LISA BOOTHE, "THE FIVE" CO-HOST: No, they're beating up Frederica Wilson because she's essentially hanging her hat on this horrible issue to try to get national attention and to build up her name as evidenced by what she said on air that now she is a rock star. What a despicable way to become a household name for this very issue. And I think -- do anyone else feel like we've hit rock bottom in society? This entire week I just felt so dirty. And I think John Kelly came out there yesterday, and what he said was so sobering. What I think we saw from him was just a desperation to get back to a place in society where there's respect, where there's dignity, where anything is sacred. And what I find so sad is that another widow of a fallen soldier felt so compelled because of this pile on President Trump who released a private conversation that she had with the president, where he told her that her husband was a hero, come to the White House anytime, she said that at such a low point, she felt like she was talking to another human. And I just think we've reached such a sad place in society that this is now a week long story. And now someone like General Kelly who served this country so valiantly is now under attack and being labeled racist? It is all just so disgusting and so dirty.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It is disgusting. You know, that why I say, I think when you make these charges you better know what you're talking about because it has real ways -- otherwise, I think it disparages people unnecessarily. But I will say that the woman that you're talking about said that the president spoke to her in a way that was comforting. But this week, we've also learned what he apparently promise some guy $25,000 and didn't pay him until this week, those families. And don't forget, he's had a situation now with the woman who, you know, Frederica Wilson, the congresswoman, where his account really varies from the reality. The mother of the dead soldiers said she was offended by what the president said.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: A few things, Juan, just to make sure we have all the facts correct. President Obama had also say the check in the mail when he made some promises about giving money to some fallen people as well. We have a transcript of the remarks that Ms. Wilson gave, and she seems to take a little bit of credit. Here what she says, everybody said it's impossible. I went into attack mode. I went to the speaker. I presented it. I dashed it over to the senate and I put the senators on notice. I put it on their radar. You know what, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What are you talking about?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm talking about the speech --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You're talking about the funding --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The reference by General Kelly --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's not right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- to put the names on the building.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You're not playing straight.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's what I'm talking about. I am playing it straight.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Let me tell you why you're not playing straight.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: But do actions what matter?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And that was referenced at the briefing today. And Sarah Huckabee Sanders had a response.

utterances.speaker: SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.sentences: General Kelly said he was stun, that representative Wilson made comments at a building dedication honoring slain FBI agents about her own actions in congress, including lobbying former President Obama on legislation. As General Kelly pointed out, if you're able to make a sacred act like honoring American heroes all about yourself, you're an empty barrel. If you don't understand that reference, I will put it more simply. As we say in the south, all hat, no cattle.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The fact you've seen the speech?

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: I have.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And that you know that most of it was her effusively praising these FBI agents. And when she was talking about what she did in congress, she was not talking about securing $20 million.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.sentences: What he said there was a lot of grandstanding. He was stun that she has taken the opportunity to make it about herself.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: My goodness. Jesse, you see what that was?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes,

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: She was talking about her ability to get the building name for two slain FBI agents, not the funding. When you're reading that, you're deceiving the audience.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm not deceiving the audience. She's acting like a braggart and taking credit --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Do you know what I say?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I say it's all unicorn, no horn. Look, can we all agree that these stories are like -- what happens is -- uh, these are bad stories because whether it's football kneeling or it's funerals, what it seems infused with politics and the next step is racial politics and we start picking at the scab. We can't stop until another scab erupts and we pick it up. Where do we want to end up with identity politics? If America is internally eating each other alive, what is the solution?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Stop. Stop. And it's incumbent upon the media to say, who cares if this is good for ratings, it's bad for the country.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow. That's strong. But don't you think that Donald Trump plays it?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think we're all guilty.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: No, absolutely. But what does she have to gain by this kind of behavior and, you know, just really horrific towards Gold Star families, racist towards General Kelly, stepping on the back of Gold Star families? I don't like it at all. And I'm quite certain the American people don't like it. It's very much so conduct unbecoming.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And General Kelly is a Gold Star parent.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And now he is under attack. So there you have it. The liberal media is trying to twist the Clinton uranium scandal to make it go away. See how, next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Instead of focusing on the Clinton uranium scandal, a scheme organized by Russia to benefit the Clintons, the far left media is mostly ignoring the story and, of course, mocking President Trump instead.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: What do you make of the, sort of, yearning (INAUDIBLE) with Hillary Clinton --

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: -- also a little frightening at this point?

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Look, there is a moral vacuum in the White House right now. And when the president is tweeting about a political opponent from a year ago, it is --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, what did you just say, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What? Those two make me throw up?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So they talk about how Trump has some yearning obsession with Hillary. They have Trump tattooed on their brain. It's like -- what's his name? Morning Joe, he's like a spurned lover. He's like -- you know what he is? He's like the runner-up bachelorette after the rejection and they try to pretend like it doesn't matter, but it's on their face, that it's driving them crazy that they didn't get picked.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They're crying in the limo --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: In the limo.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He's crying in the limo. We've all been there, though. We've all cried in a limo.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Speak for yourself.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Go on.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You've made people cry in a limo.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: In a nice way.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Can we just fathom for a minute. If this was the Trump administration and all the stuff was going on, the fact that the Justice Department had this investigation going on. And mind you, Hillary Clinton was sitting on the board that approved the uranium one deal and was also secretary of state at the time, not to mention the fact that some of these individuals, these shareholders of uranium, gave $145 million to the Clinton Foundation. I mean, can we just imagine for a minute if that she was on the other foot and how nuts some of the very other people that we just showed would be going right now? I guarantee this is not in Hillary Clinton's book, What Happened. Yet, she was talking about all the other Russia stuff that there's no evidence of. It's just a complete and utter double standard.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: It really is. I mean, how about -- this story should be number one, top-of-the-line, covered, investigated. There is actual meat on those bones.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They sure are. You know, I agree with Tim Kaine. There is a moral vacuum in the country. It's not the White House. It's over at MSNBC. You have hard news journalist at respective outlets reporting that there is a pay for play deal with the Clintons and the Russians, and you have Hillary's running mate teed up to ask about that. And then you don't even ask about it, you try to divert? I mean, come on. Bill Clinton was in Moscow. Bill has taken half a million dollars. She's signing of on deals. Everyone's getting rich. And no one cares. And I get that certain shows are soft on Trump. I get certain shows are hard on Trump. But they were so clumsy and blatant about diverting this a way to protect the Democrats. And it makes you think, come on, you guys have no credibility anymore. And he's right they're all like spurned lovers. What it is? Trump is obsessed with Hillary? Hillary wrote a book. What happened?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Obama spent years blaming Bush. Talk about obsession. That's the real obsession.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: you know, let me -- as a Democrat sitting here, let me just make the case against the (INAUDIBLE) because you're talking about credibility. I think when you have a foundation, and you have a foundation taking money from people overseas it's going to invite suspicion of quid pro quo activity, especially when the wife of the person who's running the foundation is secretary of state in the United States. But --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Preach.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- let me just say this. So I'm very curious about this because my suspicion initially was this is politics that Trump is under investigation on the Russia stuff so he's throwing this stuff out there. The right-wing media, all the right-wing media sites are hot for this story. Let me check it out. Let me see. Well, it turns out this story broke more than a year ago by the left-wing New York Times. So the story has been two years. It's been out there. OK. Second thing, when people ask the FBI agent who are around at the time about it, including agents in charge of it say we didn't even know about it. It's possible that Clinton didn't know about it. Third, there's a whole committee of people, including Eric Holder, the attorney general, and others on this committee of foreign investment that had to make the call. Not just Hillary Clinton.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: But it's not just this. It's also things like Fusion GPS --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: -- the Wall Street Journal editorial board had an article about this, where's there's this just complete -- nobody is interested in the mainstream media about Fusion GPS and the dossier and what role it had in spurring a federal investigation. And so, the Wall Street Journal is basically writing this editorial board, pay attention to this, but nobody is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I go back to the simple question. Does America really need money that bad to sell uranium to Russia? It's like selling crack to Charlie Sheen. Nothing good comes from it. We have other things that we could sell. What if we sell them the NFL?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh, gosh.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I was waiting for that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Two former presidents blasting the current state of politics in America. Their words, the more of you know who, next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yesterday, two former presidents stepped back in the spotlight to weigh in on current affairs in today's political climate in America. Barack Obama and George W. Bush making headlines with their remarks at two separate public events.

utterances.speaker: GEORGE W. BUSH, FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: In recent decades, public confidence in our institutions has declined. Our governing class has often been paralyzed in the face of obvious and pressing needs. The American dream of upward mobility seems out of reach for some who feel left behind in a changing economy. Discontent deepened and sharpened partisan conflicts. Bigotry seems emboldened. Our politics seems more vulnerable to conspiracy theories. And outright fabrication.

utterances.speaker: BARACK OBAMA, FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: Instead of our politics reflecting our values, we've got politics infecting our communities. Instead of looking for ways to work together and get things done in a practical way, we've got folks who are deliberately trying to make folks angry. To demonize people who have different ideas.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Jesse, here you have two former presidents speaking out, Republican and Democrat, you heard earlier in the week from senator McCain, Bob Corker said stuff. It seems like everyone is saying something. Sometimes they don't mention President Trump by name, but they all seem to be talking about it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right. Because Trumpism is a rejection of Obama policies and Bush policies. Everything that's come under attack, think about it, comprehensive immigration reform, Obamacare, trade deals, climate deals, nuclear deals, NATO, nation-building, and not only that, Trump is going after institutions. He's gone after the CIA, the FBI, the military- industrial complex, the RNC, the DNC, and his attacks against Bush, I think he took it personally. Remember, he went after Jeb pretty harshly, daddy's boys, all that stuff. He made a couple of comment about 9/11 in the debate in South Carolina, that were quite personal. And he's gone after President Obama relentlessly, especially talking about his legacy under attack. The Iran deal, Obamacare, everything has been ripped to shreds, almost. So it's not only policy too. Their demeanors are totally different. You have Bush who came up as an elitist from a political family whose family was about public service. President Obama, mixed race, raised in Hawaii by his grandparents, more of a community organizer. And then you just have a brash businessman who grew up in Queens, hypercompetitive, and much more rough and gruff than these guys. And he doesn't play by the rules. So I don't mind hearing W and Obama saying these things. I didn't think these attacks were that sharp. So I think it's fine. They're getting paid very well. They've got to give the crowd a little, you know, red meat.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Lisa, do you think that there's any -- the way Jesse sees it, it's personal.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: A little bit. And policy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK. But I was just thinking they're not talking about policy. They're not even talking in personal terms. They're saying something is wrong in the country when you have this much division, where people are demonized by each other. And in one case that, you know, it's blasphemy, one president said, when you have white supremacy being bantered about.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, you also saw President Obama passed something like Obamacare on party lines which is deeply divisive, right? So, I mean, you could go -- and George W. Bush also said that these things have been happening for a really long time in this country. All you have to do is look at congress throughout the previous administrations, the blockade there, the partisanship in congress has been something that's been going on for a long time. You look at something like racial tension, that gallop has been tracking, and it's been increasing year after year even under the Obama administration. There were polls during the Obama administration saying that racial tensions have gotten significantly worse under his watch. So I don't think that it's fair to point to President Trump as somehow the root of all these problems that have been existing for a while. You even look at the partisanship and divide in both the parties, the fact that Republicans had 17 candidates in the Republican Party. The fact that the DNC was on board with Hillary Clinton, which showed a lot of division of the Democrat Party. So I just think it's unfair to point to Trump.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So Greg --

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: To President Trump, rather. Sorry.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Greg, I come to you on this point that President Bush said he thinks that our politics have fallen prey to conspiracy theories and outright fabrication at this moment. Again, under Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think it's under all presidents that there's been conspiracies. I've heard enough of them. There's nothing wrong with this country. It's actually us, as part of the media-academic complex, that's where the division is coming from, the way news is covered on CNN, and that sow division in terms of justice and law and order. As for President Obama talking about how politics has infected our communities. He was a community organizer. That was his job: to infuse communities with politics.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The point is he only favors a certain kind of activation. He liked it when it happened amongst progressives. Not too much among conservatives. Now to George Bush, who I admire. His words were thoughtful, perhaps more about Bannon than Trump. But he is referring to words and not deeds. If you look at what's happening right now under President Trump, you know, we've not invaded a country. China is involved in dealing with North Korea. We have a -- highly competent responses to hurricanes. We pulled out of a terrible climate deal. We are routing, destroying ISIS. We've rolled back regulation with no consequences. There has been no large terror attack like 9/11. So one could argue, for now. Knock on wood. [KNOCKING ON DESK]

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Gee.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We can argue that things are better now than they were under either of those presidents. You could argue that. I'm not going to argue that, but what I'm saying is that what they are focusing on, they are focusing on the same things that we talked about in the "A" block, that it exists in this media-academic bubble. Emotional conflicts and arguments, dissent, arguments over phone calls and kneeling and tweets. But actual deeds, actual things that are happening in the world, how has your life changed? If you look at your 401(k), it's probably getting better. The terrorists are vanishing. That's a good thing. Consumer confidence is rising, and unemployment is down. These are action and deeds; these are not emotions. So I would say they are right about a certain mood if you are existing in a certain bubble. But when you get out, people's lives are improving.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Don't you think that's why all the focus is on all this other stuff?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: So the thing is that I prefer to not have, you know, either of the former presidents, you know, speak to this issue. I think, to be fair, the right thing to do is to give President Trump and this country and Congress the chance to continue to move forward. That's the policy, usually, that people have embraced and shown in a very professional way. And I think the country would appreciate that. But that being said, you know, they're entitled to their opinion, and I think it's a matter of policy, as well. Let's see what happens.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Kimberly. Wonder where Ms. Dana Perino is today?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh. She's at the White House. And you're going to find out why. We're going to check in with Dana next.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Tonight I'm sitting in for Dana, in Dana Perino's chair, obviously. I'm not her. She's down in Washington, D.C., where she just wrapped up an interview with Sarah Huckabee Sanders. The interview will air on "Fox News Sunday" this weekend, and Dana is sitting in for Chris Wallace, which is so cool. She joins us now for a preview.  Hey, Dana. DANA PERINO, "THE DAILY BREIFING" HOST: Hi, how are you guys?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Doing well. So Dana, you obviously have such a cool perspective sitting down with Sarah Huckabee Sanders, having held that job yourself. What can we expect from this interview?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I wanted to do something like I did with Josh Earnest back in December for "The Five," which is to just take us out of news of the day and just talk about what it's like to have the job. So she's the third woman to have the job, the second Republican woman, but she is the first working mother to ever be White House press secretary. And so I asked her a little bit about that and how she manages with three children under the age of five, or five and under. And I have to say, it was quite a fun homecoming to come back. There's a lot of reporters here and crew that I knew when I worked here. And then just to meet some of her staff and to see how she runs a really good shop where they're having a little bit of fun, but they know they've got important work to do.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Very cool. Dana, I think Jesse has got a question for you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Let's get in the nitty-gritty here. We want some color, Ms. Perino. What did you have for lunch? Did you eat at the White House, and was it good? What's changed? Did you go behind the podium and reminisce? And what is everybody gossiping about? Are they talking about how they love "The Five" at the White House?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes, definitely. That was the first thing everybody told me. But actually, I wish I had a picture to show you. I will bring you one. So after the interview, I didn't actually eat lunch here. I actually didn't eat lunch, but I'm going to fix that in just a minute. I came here after the daily briefing, my "Daily Briefing" show and her briefing. We spent about an hour and a half together. But then afterwards, I was in the briefing room. We're waiting for this hit. And guess who comes in? Jack Hanna.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Jack --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Jack Hanna, and he got to have a picture with felt Jasper. So I'm pretty sure I made his day.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Perfect end to a perfect day.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: All right. Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Um --

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I thought you had a question.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm glad, Dana -- I'm glad you accepted filling in on "Fox News Sunday" after I turned it down. As you know for me, Sunday is the day of the Lord; it's when I rest. But far be it from you to turn down --

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: What is wrong with you? Good gosh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I have a question for you. Sarah Huckabee Sanders, obviously, she has her famous dad. Could you ask her what it's like to have a socialist for a father who lost horribly to Hillary, who cheated him out of the nomination?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, I don't think so. But I did talk to her a little bit about her dad.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Bernie.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I know who you're talking about.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, answer the question. Why are you evading the question?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I can -- I'm feeling a lot like Ed Henry right now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Boo!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Boo!

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Dana's showing off her press secretary skills by deflecting. All right. Kimberly, please help us here. We need help.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Greg over there lost his turn. All right. Dana, I'm so happy to see you, and I'm really excited about you hosting this weekend.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Excited about -- I know you really wanted to get the interview with Sarah Sanders, so that's going be really compelling to see the two of you sit down and discuss you having had the job and her in the position now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You should stand! Don't sit down.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: What else do you have in store? What's on the rundown this Sunday?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK. So this is pretty exciting. I'm doing this for one week only. Chris Wallace is going to be back, and they'll probably never let me do it again. But in for the meantime, for Sunday, the OMB director, Mick Mulvaney, is going to be on, and it's pretty good timing, because the Senate Republicans just passed that budget --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- which gives them that clear runway for tax reform. So we have him. I have Senator Mitch McConnell. I have somebody that you know, the attorney general of California, Xavier Becerra --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- who's got a lot of beefs with this administration.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Xavier.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And then Sarah Sanders for a fun little segment. And I hope people tune in, because they see her every day at the briefing. But I think you'll see just yet another dimension to her, where she's really warm, smart, a great mom, and really loves this country and what she's doing. So I love sitting with her. And then I'll have a panel with Jason Chaffetz, Conn Tinetti (ph), Juan Williams --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And somebody else, Julie Pace of the A.P.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Fantastic.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I think Juan wants to know what you're going to ask him?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's always helpful. That's always helpful. Dana, you know, one of the things I always am amazed at when I get back into the briefing room, is how many people now are in that room. It used to be a pretty select group of reporters. But now, I don't -- this is going to sound awful to people, but it's like a cattle call in there at the moment, I think. How does it strike you?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, this is a very rare Friday afternoon, because it's quiet. As Sarah Sanders told me, that usually on Fridays they've -- there's some big news. They've done a lot of firings on Fridays, and so there's been a lot of things happening. Tonight, actually, Erin Landers (ph) and I and a hair and makeup are the only ones in here.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Hey, did you ask her about, you know, her -- the previous boss, Sean Spicer?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, the one thing I asked her was that, what was it like when you became the press secretary? Because I think some people, if they think they want to have this job one day, they imagine that when you get the job, it's like some big, fabulous thing where the stars come out. And there's a band, and it's this beautiful Cinderella story. My story wasn't like that. And certainly, hers was not, because she said there was about four hours between thinking that Sean Spicer was the press secretary and her finding out it was going to be her. But she said that she really appreciated that Sean was here for, I think, another six weeks or so and that it really helped her with the transition.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Dana, we're all looking forward to watching you. We know you're going to be doing great.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Thanks. And I'll be back on Monday.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yay!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Boo!

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Make sure to catch Dana's interview with Sarah Huckabee Sanders on "Fox News Sunday" at 2 p.m. Eastern. "Facebook Friday" is coming up next, so don't go anywhere.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Tonight, it's "Facebook Friday." The questions answered now. All right. This is a great question. And a question only "The Five" could answer. From Geri T.: "What is the most embarrassing moment that has happened to each of you while on the air?" Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, boy, so on this show --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I know, a lot to choose from, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's true. I have a whole life. That's right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This show. Joking. I'm joking.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think the worst was when FOX was getting started. In the Washington bureau, there was some hearings going on, and Brit Hume was hosting. So I was there with Brit as the commentator, arguing what Brit about what was taking place. And then Brit said, "Hey, can you just hold this for a second?" I say, "OK." So suddenly, I'm on the air. Nobody's there. And I found myself trying to vamp -- and I'm thinking, "What is going on?" And when Brit got back, he's like "What are you doing!" I said, "I'm doing what you told me to do!"

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I think I saw this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What is going on?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's amazing!

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: So crazy. We've got to get -- we've got to find that clip.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Kimberly. Come on, cough it up.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I mean, OK. So embarrassing, or like, gross or -- ?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Gross is good.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Totally. OK, so probably New Year's Eve. Remember?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Midnight.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You were kissed. Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Twice.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Correct!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. America --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Trying to put that behind me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Most embarrassing moment on air? Google me. Go for it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: There's a highlight reel!

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: There's a website.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What about when I wore the short suit on "Outnumbered"?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes, that we bought you at J.Crew? That was hilarious. It was a seersucker little pantsuit, like a little boy's suit with, like little shorts and --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, too short. Were those shorts?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes. It was -- that was a little special.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What about that pink jacket?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, that was dapper.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: The Ron Burgundy thing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What about you?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm sure I've done embarrassing things, like every time I'm on TV, but two things I remember specifically. I was trying to explain the appropriations process, and I was just kind of getting started on this. And I was on "Lou Dobbs," and Lou Dobbs looks at me, and he goes, "Lisa, do you think everyone's eyes are glazed over right now?"

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: No!

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I swear to God. And I was just kind of starting out. So I was like, "Oh, my God. Where do I go from here? How do you recover?"

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: When Lou Dobbs says you're boring, that's boring.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: And then another time, I tried to say "recidivism," but it took me, like -- I was on "Outnumbered." I swear it probably took me, like, five or six times. I think I eventually got it. But it was almost at that point like you have to get it, because it's just so embarrassing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Greg's eyes just glazed over.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, I was also on Lou Dobbs. Tripped and fell.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Eww!

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Am I not picking up?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Thank you for laughing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No fault fall (ph).

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: My most embarrassing? "Hannity and Colmes" when I lived -- was living in London. The show was, like, at 9 p.m., so it was like six hours, so it was, like, 3 a.m. Obviously, the pubs had closed. And I was up there, and I was sitting up there alone. And I didn't -- and I was -- let's just say you can probably look it up and find it. But Colmes -- Colmes saved me, because I was trying to say a word, but I was, like, so out of it, I couldn't say the word. Because I was so nervous. And he dove in and took it away.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You were nervous, Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I was nervous.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's what you're calling it, nervous?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, nervous.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: There's going to be a lot of Googling after this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Bob J. asks, "If you could be inside the mind of one person for a day, who would you choose?" Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yours, Gutfeld. And I would need more than one day to figure out what was going on.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You'd find some strange things.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I would.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You'd find some answers to some disturbing mysteries.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: None of which I needed to know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Exactly! Those strange disappearances in a cornfield. Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Be excited. I'm going to pick you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, really?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: And I would actually then feel so much even better about what's going on with me if I was inside your head. I'm like, OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: "There's a little room in here. This is spacious."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What about you, Lisa? Any head you'd want to be inside?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I think the president's. It would just be fun. Why not?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Good choice.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know, I would pick somebody that I find highly competitive like, to the point where -- I mean, so in my lifetime, it was people like Larry Bird, Michael Jordan, Tom Brady.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Athletes, then?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Because I'd like to know how they see the field. Because I remember once we --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Joe Montana.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Bill Bradley.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Remember the former great basketball players for the Knicks and Princeton. There was a book about him by John McPhee, and it talked about just seeing things differently. People talk about the hockey player, Wayne Gretzky, that he didn't see the puck. He saw where the puck was going to be. And I'd like to have that experience.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I would like to be in the heads of all my fans. Oh, this is real quick. This is from Colonna F? Colon-a?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Colonel?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, no, no it's not.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's not spelled that way. It's an actual name.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: OK, go.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: No pressure.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "If you were all on the original 'Star Trek' television series, which roles would you envision yourself in?" Quickly, Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: The captain, obviously.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You mean what's his name?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Captain Kirk.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There you go. Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I'd like to be Spock.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Those are the only two characters I know. Spock or Kirk.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I don't know if I've ever watched a full episode.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Nobody?

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I don't know. Who would I want to be?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm obviously going to say Obi-Wan. Anyway --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's "Star Wars."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Gosh, what a fail. Poor Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's time now for "One More Thing." I smell a good one, K.G.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: You do, indeed!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Sorry about that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: It's time -- ruining it again. Yes, there it is.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Time for "Kimberly Food Court."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: And I even gave you one of these to eat.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's the problem.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Chick-fil-A. So Jesse is enjoying, Juan again, Lisa, Greg, a little snack. So Chick-fil-A is doing this whole new spicy thing here. But not I guess you can't get it in New York, but these taste fine, good enough. So the fast food world just got a little hotter, because they announced they are testing two new flavors, Greg -- so this is going to upset your stomach -- in response to customers' response for spicy, right? People love the spice. There's Spicy Chicken Strips and Grilled Spicy Chicken Deluxe sandwich are being tested in select markets for a limited time. How does it taste? Good?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So good.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: They're seasoned with a blend of peppers, and the Spicy Chicken Deluxe sandwich has a new cilantro lime sauce. All right. So feast on that. Cheers.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't know how I'm going to top this, but this is how.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh, you've got to go to Philadelphia.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I have all five current living presidents on my show this weekend.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Nice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, indeed. I am live Saturday night. Everybody, including Jimmy Carter, will be on my show, "Watters' World." Just kidding. We're taping them live for a relief concert during the 8 p.m. hour, but they're going to be doing lots of fun presidential things, so make sure to tune into "Watters World" Saturday, 8 p.m.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's interesting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Greg Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: A lot of presidents.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Do you have anything good, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I do. Thanks for asking, Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: You're welcome.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "The Greg Gutfeld Show" tomorrow, 10 p.m., we're going to have the guy who killed bin Laden. That's the guy on the left, Rob O'Neill. Small accomplishment. And then first-time guests Katie Frates, Katherine Timpf, and of course, Tyrus. But today it's a very special day. It's my favorite day. International Sloth Day. Celebration of all things sloth. I was very upset with Fox News, because we did not get the day off. We had to come in and work on International Sloth Day.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Didn't you do this before?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's the slowest mammal. Did you know that? It sleeps 15-20 hours a day, much like Lou Dobbs. Can't get him out of bed. And they're surprisingly good swimmers. They sometimes fall directly from rainforest trees into rivers and stroke efficiently with their long arms. I apologize to anybody who might find that offensive. But they are sloths.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: You like sloths.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They have sticky claws.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Can you top that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I couldn't try. I couldn't try, because I agree. We should've had the day off. The annual Al Smith Dinner was last night here in New York. It brought some of Washington's most powerful politicians to the big city. Great event with the top leaders in the Catholic church and a lot of laughs. And this year, the star role went to the speaker of the House, Paul Ryan. He had some fun at President Trump's expense.

utterances.speaker: REP. PAUL RYAN, R-WIS., SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE
utterances.sentences: The press absolutely misunderstands and never records the big accomplishments of the White House. Look at all of the new jobs that the president has created. Just among the White House staff. Every morning, I wake up in my office, and KI scroll Twitter to see which tweets that I'll have to pretend that I did not see later on.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: He was pretty funny. He got great reviews, by the way, from all the politicians. Everybody loved it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That was pretty good. OK, Lisa.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: We've heard of bad news bears, but check out these backyard bears.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: What are they doing with our swings?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Playing with our swings.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Because they're just little cubs.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: They're cubs? Hey, that's my swing!

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: That is Tim Gonklin's (ph) home in East Granby, Connecticut, and that was his daughter's swing, and she was concerned because the baby cubs were taking it over. I don't blame her.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wow. That's what I call em-bear-assing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They'll eat you. They're cute, but they'll eat you alive.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Don't trust them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And they will destroy sloths, as well.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's who would win in a fight. You'd stand no chance, sloths.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I was wondering.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of "The Five." We're going to see you here back on Monday. "Special Report" up next.
